did.head: Collection Overview
did.unittitle: American Council for Polish Culture Collection.

repository.label: Location:
repository.corpname: Connecticut Polish American Archives, Elihu Burritt Library, Central Connecticut State University

did.abstract: American Council for Polish Culture (ACPC) is one of the oldest Polish American cultural organizations. Beginning in 1948, and still existing today, the ACPC serves as a national umbrella organization for many local cultural clubs and organizations. The ACPC collection chronicles a wide range of the organization’s activities. It illustrates the beginning, changes and development of the organization supported with extensive correspondence, minutes, reports and annual conventions materials.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The American Council of Polish Cultural Clubs (ACPCC) was established, with its constitution and by-laws, in 1948 in Detroit during the fifth conference of Polish cultural clubs. Before this, there was a movement among Polish art and cultural clubs consisting of extensive discussions among Polonia's professionals and religious groups and community leaders about the importance of cultural sensitivity among Polish Americans. The main purpose was to promote cultural advancement among Polish American communities by providing information on cultural roots, creating a sense of pride of heritage, as well as preserving and popularizing cultural organizations, which served as ambassadors of Polish culture across the country. The Council is governed by officers and a board of directors elected at annual conventions.

The movement to promote and foster cultural awareness among Polish Americans began in the 1920's. The first cultural club, the Polish Arts Club of Chicago, was established in 1926. This was followed by Polanie in Minneapolis, Minn. 1927, Club Polonaise in Passaic, NJ in 1933, and the Polish Arts Club of Youngstown, OH in 1935. More formed later from informal cultural groups in various states. To foster better communication among these groups, the annual national conference was organized. The first one took place in New York City in 1939, then in Milwaukee in 1940, and Grand Rapids 1941. Annual conferences were interrupted by the war and several years later the 4th conference took place in Chicago in 1947. It was at this time that the formation of an organization on the national level was proposed and approved. For a short period of time, the name was changed to The American Council of Polish Cultural Organization (ACPCO); this was during Blanka Rosenstiel presidency (1984-1986). It was changed to reflect proposed changes in the mission of the organization, however it did not receive acceptance from all members and the name went back to The American Council for Polish Cultural Clubs. The name change from The American Council for Polish Cultural Clubs (ACPCC) to The American Council for Polish Culture (ACPC) was proposed in 1987 and became official in 1988 during the convention in Hartford, Connecticut, and it remains the official name till today. All three versions of the name are in use in various publications but it is still the same organization. The council accepts institutional and individual members and currently has about 250 members.

Main activities of the ACPC include organizing annual conventions, sponsoring lectures, musical recitals, poetry readings, art exhibits and awarding scholarships. Another important venue is publishing. From the very beginning communication among members was established with newsletters and bulletins. First publication was the National Polish Arts Bulletin in 1946 followed by The Quarterly Review of Polish Heritage and later the Polish Heritage, which still continues today. There was also an annual publication for conventions in form of anniversary pamphlets and annual reports. The council also contributes and supports publication of books and promotes exchange of cultural programs among affiliated clubs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of the Collection
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of material covering years 1940-2013, which includes: administrative and general correspondence; convention programs, minutes and reports; various clubs activities. Also official publications for ACPC conventions and publications from affiliated members.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Mr. Charles A. Baretski was a member and archivist/historian of the organization for almost 30 years. He originally arranged the records and related material chronologically by date with the main focus on conventions as major undertaking of the organization each year. The Conventions were culminations of efforts by the governing body of the organization during their business sessions. Therefore as a wish of a donor, the original arrangement is kept within the collection.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Cite as: American Council for Polish Culture Collection (CPAA 96-03). Connecticut Polish American Archives, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The Connecticut Polish American Archives (CPAA) was selected as a repository for the papers of American Council of Polish Culture in 1990's. The first part of the papers was donated to the CPAA during a formal presentation in New Britain in December 1994. The second part of material was donated in 1996 and in 2001 seven boxes were donated by Gregory Biestek, a treasurer and archivist of ACPC. In 2013 material covering years 2003-2005 and 2010-2013 was sent to CPAA by the treasurer of the organization.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: For related material see the following collections:

Polish Cultural Club of Greater Hartford records CPAA 86-30
